prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Central Hub
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim at mapping CO species (13CO and C18O), CS, C34S, SO, 34SO and H-C40alpha toward the hub in MonR2 (see Fig. 1 in the Scientific Justification). We plan to cover an area of 4.7'x4.7', i.e., a mosaic of 126 pointing. Based on previous observations, we expect intensity lines between 100 mJy (for the most extended emision in the H40a and C40a lines) and 2.276 Jy (18K for the most compact peak in the 13CO line). We are asking for a sensitivity of about 36 mJy (0.3 K), for an angular resoluton of 3.5" (about 8-9 times better that our previous IRAM-30m observations) and a espectral resolution of 0.2 km/s. Thus, we will achieve a S/N between 3-4 and 60. The estimated total time for the science goal is 1.71 hours, in the compact configuration C36-1.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use the ALMA correlator capabilities to observe simultaneously 8 different spectral line transitions in band 3. The highest spectral resolution that we request is 0.2 km/s, although some lines can be observed with a resolution of 0.4 km/s (see below). For all the lines we cover a velocity range of around 160 km/s.
- Requested spectral lines and resolution: We have set 4 spectral windows (in basebands 1 and 2) with a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (155--160 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 70.5 kHz (0.16 km/s). These windows will be used to cover the transitions of 13CO, C18O, C34S, and 34SO. We plan to smooth the spectral resolution down to 0.2 km/s. This number is necessary in order to study the velocity gradients (of a few km/s) and the different velocity components (separated by a few km/s) observed in the IRAM-30m maps (see Figure 1). Considering 1 km/s as the typical velocity change that we want to study, we need a resolution of 0.2 km/s in order to have at least 5 spectral resolution elements.
In addition, we have set 2 spectral windows (in baseband 3), with a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (177 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 122.0 kHz (0.37 km/s) to cover the spectral lines of CS, SO; and 2 additional spectral windows (in baseband 3), with a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (177 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 141.1 kHz (0.43 km/s) to cover the spectral lines of H40alpha and C40alpha. The recombination lines (H40alpha and C40alpha) have a linewidth of typically a few 10 km/s, therefore, a resolution of about 0.4 km/s is good enough to sample the lines. The IRAM-30m observations of sulfurated species like CS and SO (Trevino-Morales et al, in prep) reveal line-widths typically 2 times larger than for other species, thus a resolution of about 0.37-0.4 km/s is still enough to sample the lines.
Finally, in baseband 4 we have set a spectral window of 1875.0 MHz to observe the continuum emission.
- Requested velocity coverage: The requested bandwidth for the line observations is typically of about 160 km/s. This is enough to cover the different velocity components and linewidths (spanning a range from 3 to 15 km/s), and to provide enough line-free channels to determine the continuum level.
- Data rate, spectral averaging: In order to decrease the data rate, we have applied spectral averaging for some of the spectral units. The spectral resolution indicated above is the output of the spectral-averaging process.

We request an angular resolution of 3.5 arcsec, a maximum recoverable angular scale of 100 arcsec, and a total field of view of about 4.7'x4.7' (i.e., a mosaic of 126 pointings).
- Requested field of view: The size of the hub, according to Herschel maps, is about 1x1 pc^2. Therefore, we plan to cover its extension by mapping an area of 4.7x4.7 arcmin^2 (or in linear scales: 1.1x1.1 pc^2). The area is indicated by a yellow box in Figure 1 (in the Scientific Justification). At the requested frequencies, this implies a mosaic of 126 pointings.
- Requested angular resolution: The size of the cores in star forming regions is typically a few 0.01 pc. Similarly, recent interferometric observations carried out with CARMA (Lee et al 2014; Fernandez-Lopez et al 2014; S. Suri, private communication) or with ALMA (Sanchez-Monge et al 2014) have revealed that the width of filaments can be as narrow as a few 0.01 pc. Therefore, we request a linear resolution of about 0.01 pc (or 3.5 arcsec) to be able to resolve such structures.
- Requested largest angular scale: Our IRAM-30m maps reveal extended emission tracing filamentary arms converging towards the central part of the region (where the UCHII region is located). The width of these structures extends up to 50-100 arcsec. In order to be sensitive to all the spatial scales from 0.01 pc to 0.4 pc, we request the use of the ACA and TP. We also note, that in order to properly study the structure and kinematics of the filaments, a high fidelity image is necessary, and only ALMA can provide it by combining the 12m array, the 7m ACA array, and the TP single-dishes.

The main goal is the study of the hub emission in different CO species, that will be complemented with simultaneous observations of denser gas tracers (CS, C34, SO, 34SO) and ionized gas tracers (H40a, C40a). The requested sensitivity is 0.3 K (36 mJy) for a 3.5 arcsec beam, and per 0.2 km/s channel. This will permit to reach 3 < S/N < 60.
- Requested line/continuum sensitivity: The 13CO emission line (as well as all the other molecules) is bright at the central hub position. Based on previous IRAM-30m observations of the same transition (1-0), we expect line intensities from a few K (typically higher than 4K, equivalent to 500 mJy) for the most extended and weak emission, up to 18 K (2.3 Jy) for the brightest peaks. The C18O line presents a narrower and weaker emission, compared to 13CO. The IRAM-30m maps of the (1-0) transition reveal emission in the range from 1K (126 mJy; for extended emission) up to 4 K (500 mJy) for the most compact emission. Simultaneously to these lines, we plan to observe CS, C34S, SO, 34SO, H40alpha and C40alpha lines. Our unbiased spectral line survey (carried out with the IRAM-30m) reveals that the line intensities for these lines are in the range 0.9 to 3.5 K.
We aim at getting S/N > 3, which corresponds to a sensitivity of 0.3 K (or 36 mJy, for a beam of 3.5 arcsec). The sensitivity needs to be achieved in a 0.2 km/s spectral channel in order to properly study the kinematics (see below).
We note that our intensity estimates, based on previous IRAM-30m data with a 27 arcsec beam, are conservative. The inner part of the filaments, as well as dense condesations, are expected to have linear sizes of 0.01-0.1 pc, corresponding to angular scales of 3-30 arcsec. Therefore, beam dillution effects might affect the line intensities measured in the IRAM-30m data, resulting in stronger lines in the high-angular resolution ALMA observations.
Simultaneously to the line observations, we will use a 1.8 GHz continuum band which will permit to reach a sensitivity about 0.2 mJy/beam. SMA continuum observations (Dierickx et al 2015) have shown compact condensations with intensity peaks of about 100 mJy/beam (in a 2.5 arcsec beam) at 1 mm, corresponding to intensity peaks of about 4 mJy/beam at 3 mm, assuming a conservative steep spectral index of 4 (beta=2). The requested sensitivity would permit to detect similar dust condensations along the filament.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Filament F1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to mapping CO species (13CO and C18O), CS, C34S, SO, 34SO and H40alpha toward the north-south filament F1 in MonR2 (see Fig. 1 in the Scientific Justification). We plan to cover an area of 2.16'x10.83', i.e., a mosaic of 147 pointing. Based on previous observations, we expect intensity lines between 127 mJy (for the most extended emision in the C18O line) and 1.897 Jy (15K for the most compact peak in the 13CO line). We are asking for a sensitivity of about 36 mJy (0.3 K), for an angular resoluton of 3.5" (about 8-9 times better that our previous IRAM-30m observations) and a espectral resolution of 0.2 km/s. Thus, we will achieve a S/N between 3-4 and 50. The estimated total time for the science goal is 1.87 hours, in the compact configuration C36-1.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use the ALMA correlator capabilities to observe simultaneously 8 different spectral line transitions in band 3. The highest spectral resolution that we request is 0.2 km/s, although some lines can be observed with a resolution of 0.4 km/s (see below). For all the lines we cover a velocity range around 160 km/s.
- Requested spectral lines and resolution: We have set 4 spectral windows (in basebands 1 and 2) with a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (~160 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 70.0 kHz (0.16 km/s). These windows will be used to cover the transitions of 13CO, C18O, C34S and 34SO. We plan to smooth the spectral resolution down to 0.2 km/s. This number is necessary in order to study the velocity gradients (of a 1-2 km/s) and the different velocity components (separated by a 2 km/s) observed in the IRAM-30m maps (see Figure 1). Considering 1 km/s as the typical velocity change that we want to study, we need a resolution of 0.2 km/s in order to have at least 5 spectral resolution elements.
In addition, and in order to have the same spectral setup as in the central hub region, we have set 2 spectral windows (in baseband 3), with a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (177 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 122.0 kHz (0.37 km/s) to cover the spectral lines of CS, SO; and 2 additional spectral windows (in baseband 3), with a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (177 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 141.1 kHz (0.43 km/s) to cover the spectral lines of H40alpha and C40alpha.
Finally, in baseband 4 we have set a spectral window with 1875.0 MHz to observe the continuum emission.
- Requested velocity coverage: The requested bandwidth for the line observations is typically of about 170 km/s. This should suffice to cover the velocity components and linewidths expected in filament F1 (spanning a range from 2 to 5 km/s), and to provide enough line-free channels to determine the continuum level.
- Data rate, spectral averaging: In order to decrease the data rate, we have applied spectral averaging for some of the spectral units. The spectral resolution indicated above is the output of the spectral-averaging process.

We request an angular resolution of 3.5 arcsec, a maximum recoverable angular scale of 100 arcsec, and a total field of view of 2.16x10.83 arcmin^2 (i.e., a mosaic of 147 pointings).
- Requested field of view: Filament F1 extends from the central hub to the north for about 15 arcmin. However, we will cover only an extension of about 10 arcmin, corresponding to the area where the 13CO and C18O lines are brighter. The filament have a width of about 1 arcmin (0.1-0.2 pc, in agreement with single-dish observations of other star forming regions, e.g. Andre et al 2010). Therefore, the covered area is 2.16x10.83 arcmin^2, as indicated by the yellow vertical rectangle in Figure 1. At the requested frequencies, this implies a mosaic of 147 pointings.
- Requested angular resolution: The size of the cores in star forming regions is typically a few 0.01 pc. Similarly, recent interferometric observations carried out with CARMA (Lee et al 2014; Fernandez-Lopez et al 2014; S. Suri, private communication) and ALMA (Sanchez-Monge et al 2014) have revealed that the width of filaments can be as narrow as a few 0.01 pc. Therefore, we request a linear resolution of about 0.01 pc (or 3.5 arcsec) to be able to resolve such structures.
- Requested largest angular scale: The width of the filament, as revealed by our IRAM-30m maps, is about 1 arcmin, we therefore need to be sensitive to these spatial scales. Overall, we plan to resolve structures in the range from 0.01 pc to 0.2 pc, by combining the main array with ACA and TP observations. We also note, that in order to properly study the structure and kinematics of the filaments, a high fidelity image is necessary, and only ALMA can provide it by combining the 12m array, the 7m ACA array, and the TP single-dishes.

The main goal is the study of the filamentary emission in different CO species towards filament F1 (see Fig. 1 in the Scientific Justification), that will be complemented with simultaneous observations of denser gas tracers (CS, C34S, SO, 34SO). The requested sensitivity is 0.3 K (36 mJy) for a 3.5 arcsec beam, and per 0.2 km/s channel. This will permit to reach S/N > 3.
- Requested line/continuum sensitivity: The 13CO line emission along filament F1, as observed with the IRAM-30m, has an intensity that varies from 1 K (equivalent to 127 mJy in the extended emission) up to 15 K (1.9 Jy), in the brightest peaks. Similarly, the C18O line, covers a range of line intensities from 1 K (127 mJy) to 3 K (380 mJy).
We do not have 30m previous observations for CS, C34S, SO, 34SO lines in the filaments, but we expect them to trace the densest part of the filament, and to pintpoint the position of dense cores within the filament. The emission (for these lines) detected in the central hub suggests that if they are also present in the filaments, the intensities can be of about 1.5 K.
We aim at achieving S/N > 3, which corresponds to a sensitivity of 0.3 K (or 36 mJy, for a beam of 3.5 arcsec). The sensitivity needs to be achieved in a 0.2 km/s spectral channel in order to properly study the kinematics (see below).
We note that our intensity estimates, based on previous IRAM-30m data with a 27-arcsec beam, are conservative. The inner part of the filaments, as well as dense condesations, are expected to have linear sizes of 0.01-0.1 pc, corresponding to angular scales of 3-30 arcsec. Therefore, beam dillution effects might affect the line intensities masured in the IRAM-30m data, resulting in stronger lines in the high-angular resolution ALMA observations.
Simultaneously to the line observations, we will use a 1.8-GHz continuum band which will permit to reach a sensitivity of about 0.2 mJy/beam. SMA continuum observations (Dierickx et al 2015) towards the central region of MonR2, have shown compact condensations with intensity peaks of about 100 mJy/beam (in a 2.5-arcsec beam) at 1 mm, corresponding to intensity peaks of about 4 mJy/beam at 3 mm, assuming a conservative steep spectral index of 4 (beta=2). The requested sensitivity would permit to detect similar dust condensations along the filament.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Filament F3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to map CO species (13CO and C18O), CS, C34S, SO, 34SO and H-C40alpha toward the northeast filament F3 in MonR2 (see Fig. 1 in the Scientific Justification). We plan to cover an area of 2.4'x6.9', i.e., a mosaic of 109 pointing. Based on previous observations, we expect intensity lines between 127 mJy (for the most extended emision in the C18O line) and 2.150 Jy (17K for the most compact peak in the 13CO line). We are asking for a sensitivity of about 36 mJy (0.3 K), for an angular resoluton of 3.5" (about 8-9 times better that our previous IRAM-30m observations) and a espectral resolution of 0.2 km/s. Thus, we will achieve a S/N between 3-4 and 56. The estimated total time for the science goal is 1.21 hours, in the compact configuration C36-1.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use the ALMA correlator capabilities to observe simultaneously 8 different spectral line transitions in band 3. The highest spectral resolution that we request is 0.2 km/s, although some lines can be observed with a resolution of 0.4 km/s (see below). For all the lines we cover a velocity range around 160 km/s.
- Requested spectral lines and resolution: We have set 4 spectral windows (in basebands 1 and 2) with a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (~160 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 70.0 kHz (0.16 km/s). These windows will be used to cover the transitions of 13CO, C18O, C34S, and 34SO. We plan to smooth the spectral resolution down to 0.2 km/s. This number is necessary in order to study the velocity gradients (of a 1-2 km/s) and the different velocity components (separated by a 2 km/s) observed in the IRAM-30m maps (see Figure 1). Considering 1 km/s as the typical velocity change that we want to study, we need a resolution of 0.2 km/s in order to have at least 5 spectral resolution elements.
In addition, and in order to have the same spectral setup as in the central hub region, we have set 2 spectral windows (in baseband 3), with a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (177 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 122.0 kHz (0.37 km/s) to cover the spectral lines of CS, SO; and 2 additional spectral windows (in baseband 3), with a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (177 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 141.1 kHz (0.43 km/s) to cover the spectral lines of H40alpha and C40alpha.
Finally, in baseband 4 we have set a spectral window with 1875.0 MHz to observe the continuum emission.
- Requested velocity coverage: The requested bandwidth for the line observations is typically of about 170 km/s. This should suffice to cover the velocity components and linewidths expected in filament F3 (spanning a range from 2 to 5 km/s), and to provide enough line-free channels to determine the continuum level.
- Data rate, spectral averaging: In order to decrease the data rate, we have applied spectral averaging for some of the spectral units. The spectral resolution indicated above is the output of the spectral-averaging process.

We request an angular resolution of 3.5 arcsec, a maximum recoverable angular scale of 100 arcsec, and a total field of view of 2.4x6.9 arcmin^2 (i.e., a mosaic of 109 pointings).
- Requested field of view: Filament F3 extends from the central hub to the northeast. We plan to map the area of the filament that is clearly detected in our IRAM-30m maps. The extention is about 6.5 arcmin, while the width needs to be a few arcmin in order to properly cover the width of the filament (about 1 arcmin; 0.1-0.2 pc, in agreement with single-dish observations of other star forming regions, e.g. Andre et al 2010). Therefore, the covered area is about 2.4x6.9 arcmin^2, as indicated by the yellow rectangle to the northeast in Figure 1. At the requested frequencies, this implies a mosaic of 109 pointings.
- Requested angular resolution: The size of the cores in star forming regions is typically a few 0.01 pc. Similarly, recent interferometric observations carried out with CARMA (Lee et al 2014; Fernandez-Lopez et al 2014; S. Suri, private communication) and ALMA (Sanchez-Monge et al 2014) have revealed that the width of filaments can be as narrow as a few 0.01 pc. Therefore, we request a linear resolution of about 0.01 pc (or 3.5 arcsec) to be able to resolve such structures.
- Requested largest angular scale: The width of the filament, as revealed by our IRAM-30m maps, is about 1 arcmin, we therefore need to be sensitive to these spatial scales. Overall, we plan to resolve structures in the range from 0.01 pc to 0.2 pc, by combining the main array with ACA and TP observations. We also note, that in order to properly study the structure and kinematics of the filaments, a high fidelity image is necessary, and only ALMA can provide it by combining the 12m array, the 7m ACA array, and the TP single-dishes.

The main goal is to map the CO speciesin the filament F3 (see Fig. 1 in the main proposal), that will be complemented with simultaneous observations of denser gas tracers (CS, C34S, SO, 34SO) and ionized gas tracers (H40a, C40a). The requested sensitivity is 0.3 K (36.22 mJy) for a 3.5 arcsec beam, and per 0.2 km/s channel. This will permit to reach S/N > 3.
- Requested line/continuum sensitivity: The 13CO line emission along filament F3, as observed with the IRAM-30m, has an intensity that varies from 2 K (equivalent to 252 mJy, in the extended emission) up to 17 K (2.150 Jy), in the brightest peaks). Similarly, the C18O line, covers a range of line intensities from 1 K (127 mJy) to 5 K (632 mJy).
We do not have 30m previous observations for CS, C34S, SO, 34SO lines in the filaments, but we expect them to trace the densest part of the filament, and to pintpoint the position of dense cores within the filament. The emission (for these lines) detected in the central hub suggests that if they are also present in the filaments, the intensities can be of about 1.5 K.
We aim at achieving S/N > 3, which corresponds to a sensitivity of 0.3 K (or 36 mJy, for a beam of 3.5 arcsec). The sensitivity needs to be achieved in a 0.2 km/s spectral channel in order to properly study the kinematics (see below).
We note that our intensity estimates, based on previous IRAM-30m data with a 27-arcsec beam, are conservative. The inner part of the filaments, as well as dense condesations, are expected to have linear sizes of 0.01-0.1 pc, corresponding to angular scales of 3-30 arcsec. Therefore, beam dillution effects might affect the line intensities measured in the IRAM-30m data, resulting in stronger lines in the high-angular resolution ALMA observations.
Simultaneously to the line observations, we will use a 1.8-GHz continuum band which will permit to reach a sensitivity of about 0.2 mJy/beam. SMA continuum observations (Dierickx et al 2015) towards the central region of MonR2, have shown compact condensations with intensity peaks of about 100 mJy/beam (in a 2.5-arcsec beam) at 1 mm, corresponding to intensity peaks of about 4 mJy/beam at 3 mm, assuming a relatively steep spectral index of 4 (beta=2). The requested sensitivity would permit to detect similar dust condensations along the filament.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Filament F10
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We aim to map CO species (13CO and C18O), CS, C34S, SO, 34SO and Halpha toward the southwest filament F10 in MonR2 (see Fig. 1 in the Scientific Justification). We plan to cover an area of 3.0'x7.5', i.e., a mosaic of 132 pointing. Based on previous observations, we expect intensity lines between 127 mJy (for the most extended emision in the C18O line) and 1.518 Jy (12K for the most compact peak in the 13CO line). We are asking for a sensitivity of about 36 mJy (0.3 K), for an angular resoluton of 3.5" (about 8-9 times better that our previous IRAM-30m observations) and a espectral resolution of 0.2 km/s. Thus, we will achieve a S/N between 3-4 and 40. The estimated total time for the science goal is 1.76 hours, in the compact configuration C36-1.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use the ALMA correlator capabilities to observe simultaneously 8 different spectral line transitions in band 3. The highest spectral resolution that we request is 0.2 km/s, although some lines can be observed with a resolution of 0.4 km/s (see below). For all the lines we cover a velocity range around 160 km/s.
- Requested spectral lines and resolution: We have set 4 spectral windows (in basebands 1 and 2) with a bandwidth of 58.6 MHz (~160 km/s) and a spectral resolution of 70.0 kHz (0.16 km/s). These windows will be used to cover the transitions of 13CO, C18O, C34S, and 34SO. We plan to smooth the spectral resolution down to 0.2 km/s. This should suffice to cover the velocity components and linewidths expected in filament F10 (spanning a range from 2 to 5 km/s), and to provide enough line-free channels to determine the continuum level.
- Data rate, spectral averaging: In order to decrease the data rate, we have applied spectral averaging for some of the spectral units. The spectral resolution indicated above is the output of the spectral-averaging process.

We request an angular resolution of 3.5 arcsec, a maximum recoverable angular scale of 100 arcsec, and a total field of view of 3.0x7.5 arcmin^2 (i.e., a mosaic of 132 pointings).
- Requested field of view: Filament F10 extends from the central hub to the southwest. We will concentrate on the 1.5 pc that are closer to the central hub, corresponding to an extension of about 7 arcmin. In order to cover simultaneously the subfilament F10-A, we request a map with a width of 3 arcmin. The final requested covered area is 3.0x7.5 arcmin^2, as indicated by the yellow rectangle to the southwest in Figure 1. At the requested frequencies, this implies a mosaic of 132 pointings.
- Requested angular resolution: The size of the cores in star forming regions is typically a few 0.01 pc. Similarly, recent interferometric observations carried out with CARMA (Lee et al 2014; Fernandez-Lopez et al 2014; S. Suri, private communication) and ALMA (Sanchez-Monge et al 2014) have revealed that the width of filaments can be as narrow as a few 0.01 pc. Therefore, we request a linear resolution of about 0.01 pc (or 3.5 arcsec) to be able to resolve such structures.
- Requested largest angular scale: The width of the filament, as revealed by our IRAM-30m maps, is about 1 arcmin, we therefore need to be sensitive to these spatial scales. Overall, we plan to resolve structures in the range from 0.01 pc to 0.2 pc, by combining the main array with ACA and TP observations. We also note, that in order to properly study the structure and kinematics of the filaments, a high fidelity image is necessary, and only ALMA can provide it by combining the 12m array, the 7m ACA array, and the TP single-dishes.

The main goal is the study of the filamentary emission in different CO species that will be complemented with simultaneous observations of denser gas tracers (CS, C34S, SO, 34SO). The requested sensitivity is 0.3 K (36 mJy) for a 3.5 arcsec beam, and per 0.2 km/s channel. This will permit to reach S/N > 3.
- Requested line/continuum sensitivity: The 13CO line emission along filament F10, as observed with the IRAM-30m, has an intensity that varies from 1 K (127 mJy; in the extended emission) up to 12 K (1.5 Jy) in the brightest peaks. Similarly, the C18O line, covers a range of line intensities from 1 K (127 mJy) to 4 K (450 mJy).
We do not have 30m previous observations for CS, C34S SO, 34SO lines in the filaments, but we expect them to trace the densest part of the filament, and to pintpoint the position of dense cores within the filament. The emission (for these lines) detected in the central hub suggests that if they are also present in the filaments, the intensities can be of about 1.5 K.
We aim at achieving S/N > 3, which corresponds to a sensitivity of 0.3 K (or 36 mJy, for a beam of 3.5 arcsec). The sensitivity needs to be achieved in a 0.2 km/s spectral channel in order to properly study the kinematics (see below).
We note that our intensity estimates, based on previous IRAM-30m data with a 27-arcsec beam, are conservative. The inner part of the filaments, as well as dense condesations, are expected to have linear sizes of 0.01-0.1 pc, corresponding to angular scales of 3-30 arcsec. Therefore, beam dillution effects might affect the line intensities measured in the IRAM-30m data, resulting in stronger lines in the high-angular resolution ALMA observations.
Simultaneously to the line observations, we will use a 1.8 GHz continuum band which will permit to reach a sensitivity of about 0.2 mJy/beam. SMA continuum observations (Dierickx et al 2015) towards the central region of MonR2, have shown compact condensations with intensity peaks of about 100 mJy/beam (in a 2.5-arcsec beam) at 1 mm, corresponding to intensity peaks of about 4 mJy/beam at 3 mm, assuming a relatively steep spectral index of 4 (beta=2). The requested sensitivity would permit to detect similar dust condensations along the filament.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: With this proposal we aim at understanding the processes of cloud gas feeding and HII region feeback that lead to the formation of high-mass stars. We plan detailed high-spatial resolution maps in different species (13CO, C18O, CS, C34S, SO, H40a) to study the close-by (only 830 pc distance) high-mass star forming region MonR2: an expanding HII region embedded in a dense hub surrounded by converging filaments. Previous observations reveal a complex kinematics along the filaments, likely tracing the accretion of material from the outside to the central hub, where we find spiraling arms converging towards the expanding HII region. Thanks to the high-spatial scales that can be probed in this region, MonR2 is an excellent target to study the dynamic and kinematic properties of filamentary hubs in an environment of high UV radiation.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: IRAM Granada Office, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Physics I, Cologne, University of
Group of Molecular Astrophysics, ICMM CSIC
Group of Molecular Astrophysics, ICMM CSIC
School of Physics and Astronomy, Cardiff University
